article: As far back as I can remember, I've always known that my brother was different. At first I thought this was a _ thing. But when I got older I learned the truth. My brother had autism and Attention Deficit Disorder -- serious _ conditions. At 15, he _ like a 7-year-old child. When he was little, I didn't _ it as much. But as he got older, it became more obvious. When something didn't go his _ , he got angry and it took hours to _ him down. He would talk to himself and play with string. We could never _ to give him his medicine, otherwise he'd go wild. I was always _ when we took him anywhere, and I never wanted to bring any of my friends _ with me. When I was 10, I felt like I couldn't _ it any more. I'd shout at him for being different and would ask _ he couldn't be normal. Of course, he had no _ what I was talking about. It became very hard, _ when a friend of mine didn't want to come over _ her mom had said my brother was dangerous. Our fights _ up until one day he came up to me. He gave me a big _ , like he was saying, "I don't know what I did _ , but I hope you still love me." At that moment I realized that I'd better learn to _ him. As I've gotten older, I've learned how _ I really am. Having him as a brother has made me kinder and more patient. No matter how busy my _ is, he'll always listen to my problems. I worry about his future, but I know he'll always be loved.
